snippet: Two court rulings could unnecessarily cost New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority billions of dollars.
abstract: Editorial criticizes two court rulings involving transportation that could unnecessarily cost New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority billions of dollars; notes that judges rejected state laws because they supposedly ran afoul of a home-rule provision that sets certain limits on state interference in local affairs; argues that the decisions could cost the public a lot of money and they should not be allowed to stand.
lead_paragraph: Two court rulings could unnecessarily cost New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority billions of dollars.
